__data__.text: Under President Idi Amin, numerous Ugandans, including minorities, were killed or tortured. In South Africa, police brutality has escalated dramatically, with a 312% increase in incidents from 2011-2012 compared to 2001-2002. This has led to a significant number of deaths in police custody and costly civil liabilities claims against the police force, which the commissioner attributed to a litigious environment. Notably, a South African teenager with Down Syndrome, Nathaniel Julius, was fatally shot by police in Soweto for not responding to an officer. This highlights the pervasive issue of police brutality in the region.

Under President Idi Amin, numerous Ugandans faced violence and torture, while in South Africa, police brutality has risen significantly, resulting in deaths in custody and costly liabilities. A notable example is the fatal shooting of 16-year-old Nathaniel Julius, a boy with Down Syndrome, by police in Soweto for not responding to them. This incident, along with ten other deaths linked to police brutality in 2020, highlights the prevalent issue of excessive force in the region. Similarly, police violence was a significant factor in Egypt's 2011 revolution, with little improvement since. A woman in Egypt is still seeking justice for herself and jailed witnesses after reporting gang rape, despite six months of advocacy. Ethiopia also faces similar concerns.

In Egypt, a woman who reported a gang rape in 2014 is yet to receive justice, and witnesses who supported her case have been jailed, tortured, and publicly defamed. The Egyptian authorities are under criticism for not investigating the Fairmont Hotel rape case. In Bangladesh, police used excessive force against unarmed students who were protesting peacefully against the decision to make Urdu the only state language in 1952, despite the enforcement of a law banning public gatherings. This led to the use of tear gas and live ammunition against the students. Similarly, police brutality is prevalent in Uganda under President Idi Amin's regime, and in South Africa, where excessive force has resulted in deaths in custody and costly liabilities.

In Bangladesh, despite laws prohibiting public gatherings, students and protesters have been met with excessive force by police. In 1952, peaceful student protesters were dispersed with tear gas and live ammunition, resulting in deaths. In 2017, protesters against the Bangladesh India Friendship Power Company were forcibly arrested, struck, and subjected to water cannons, tear gas, and baton charges. Additionally, a man named Shamim Reja was allegedly tortured and killed in a police station in the same year. The officers involved were found guilty. These incidents highlight the prevalent police brutality in Bangladesh.

In Bangladesh and China, authorities have used excessive force against protesters, including tear gas, water cannons, and physical violence. In Bangladesh, this has resulted in deaths and highlights the issue of police brutality. Meanwhile, in China, protesters have organized through social media, even using subtle methods like peaceful walks, to demonstrate against corruption and abuse of power, particularly in the textile hub of Xintang, Canton Province. Political motivations, such as opposition to the Chinese Communist Party, have also fueled protests in China.

In both Bangladesh and China, authorities have responded to protests with excessive force, such as tear gas, water cannons, and physical violence, resulting in deaths and injuries. In China, protesters have used social media to organize peaceful demonstrations against corruption and abuse of power, even in the face of brutal police responses and installation of physical barriers around dissidents' locations. The Hong Kong SAR has seen numerous instances of police brutality during protests, including beatings of handcuffed activists and passers-by, and use of police lines to conceal demonstrators' treatment.

In the 2019-2020 Hong Kong protests, there were numerous allegations of police brutality, including the use of excessive force such as beatings, rubber bullets, and tear gas, which caused severe injuries and even death. Instances of protesters being hidden from public view and re-emerging injured were reported. A retired police officer, Frankly Chu King-wai, was convicted for causing serious harm. The police's actions, such as intentionally shooting protesters in the head with rubber bullets and rapidly tear-gassing surrounded crowds, led to many critical injuries. Many citizens believe that the police aimed to murder protesters to suppress their right to free speech. This behavior was widely condemned, including by Amnesty International, which released a report criticizing the police's role in the violent 12 June protest. Conflicts between police and protesters persisted throughout July 2019.

The 2019-2020 Hong Kong protests were marked by allegations of police brutality, including excessive use of force such as beatings, rubber bullets, and tear gas, which resulted in severe injuries and fatalities. There were also reports of protesters being hidden and re-emerging injured, as well as instances of police obstructing journalists with baton strikes. In addition, there were claims of sexual violence, disappearances, and falling deaths linked to police brutality. Similarly, in Iran, authorities have been known to use excessive force against protesters, such as in the 1979 US embassy hostage crisis and the 2009 Presidential election protests, as well as in more recent events. For example, a video in April 2018 showed a female member of Iran's morality police assaulting a woman for not complying with mandatory headscarf rules.

The police's violent actions during the 2019-2020 Hong Kong protests were widely criticized, and similar condemnation arose when Iranian authorities were accused of brutality leading to the death of Mahsa Amini in 2022, which ignited significant protests, particularly by women. Historically, authorities in Iran, Iraq (under Saddam Hussein), and Israel have been known to use excessive force against those who oppose them, as seen in events like the 1979 US embassy hostage crisis, the 2009 Presidential election protests in Iran, and India's independence struggle. In response to the Amini incident, Iran's interior ministry initiated an inquiry, and the head of Tehran's morality police was suspended.

Authorities in Iraq under Saddam Hussein, Israel, and India have a history of using excessive force against opponents. In Iraq, those who opposed Hussein were arrested, while in Israel, protestors and activists during India's independence struggle were subject to Lathi charges and shootings, including the Jallianwala Bagh massacre. In India, during the emergency of 1975-1977, there were several cases of police brutality, and in 2019, students protesting the Citizenship Amendment Act were baton-charged by police. Similar condemnation arose when Iranian authorities were accused of brutality leading to the death of Mahsa Amini in 2022, which ignited significant protests, particularly by women.

In India and Indonesia, authorities have a history of using excessive force against perceived opponents. In India, students protesting the Citizenship Amendment Act in 2019 were baton-charged by police, similar to historical Lathi charges used during protests and riots. In Indonesia, Islamic extremists have been targeted by police, often resulting in their capture or death. Instances of police corruption, such as retaliation against journalists investigating hidden bank accounts, have also occurred. The police's history of violence can be traced back to the Suharto regime (1967–1998), which was marked by an anti-Communist purge. Criminal investigations into human rights violations by the police are uncommon, punishments are typically light, and there is no effective independent national body to handle public complaints in Indonesia.

Authorities in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and the United Arab Emirates have been accused of using excessive force and violence. In India and Indonesia, police have a history of using excessive force against protesters and suspected criminals, with light punishments and rare investigations into human rights violations. In Malaysia, police have attacked protesters and used caning as a form of punishment. The Philippines has also seen instances of police brutality, with a recent incident involving a police officer shooting unarmed civilians, leading to nationwide outrage. In Singapore, protests are not allowed, and people have been caned for vandalism and other offenses. The Gulf Cooperation Council member states, including the United Arab Emirates, have also reported cases of brutality involving senior figures. Amnesty International has urged Indonesia to review its police tactics to meet international standards.

In Singapore, protests are prohibited and caning is used as a form of punishment for offenses. The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) member states, including the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Saudi Arabia, have been reported to use excessive force and violence, with examples including the torture of business associates by a UAE sheikh and the killing of a Saudi-American activist in the Saudi Embassy in Turkey. Amnesty International has called for reviews of police tactics in Indonesia and the treatment of prisoners in the UAE. Bahrain is also mentioned as a GCC member state.

In several countries, there have been issues with how law enforcement and authorities handle protests and suspects. In Singapore, protests are banned and caning is used as punishment. The GCC member states, including Saudi Arabia and the UAE, have been accused of using excessive force, such as the killing of a Saudi-American activist in Turkey and the torture of business associates by a UAE sheikh. Amnesty International has criticized police tactics in Indonesia and the treatment of prisoners in the UAE. In Bahrain, police and military personnel have been violent towards Arab Spring protesters. Pakistan's law enforcement, despite having strict laws against physical abuse of suspects, has faced allegations of police brutality, including the extra-judicial killing of Naqeebullah by an ex-officer named Rao Anwar. The Supreme Court intervened in this case. In Thailand, a rally by the People National Alliance to free Kashmir from Pakistani rule resulted in 100 people being injured due to police intervention.

Law enforcement and authorities in several countries, including Thailand and Turkey, have been criticized for their handling of protests, resulting in injuries, deaths, and allegations of excessive force and brutality. In Thailand, the police have been accused of causing harm to 100 people during a rally and using lethal force against protesters at Thammasat University in 1976. Similarly, Turkey has a history of police brutality, with excessive use of tear gas, pepper spray, and water cannons, and physical violence against protesters, particularly during Kurdish protests and May Day demonstrations. The European Court of Human Rights has criticized the lack of effective investigations into allegations of ill-treatment by Turkish law enforcement personnel. In 2021, Turkey issued a ban on audio-visual recordings of police at protests. These incidents highlight the ongoing issues with how authorities handle protests and the use of excessive force in several countries.

In Turkmenistan and Austria, particularly in Vienna, there have been concerns about how authorities handle certain situations. In Turkmenistan, there have been criticisms of the government's handling of protests, with allegations of excessive force and brutality. In Vienna, there is an association of the city's drug problem with African migrants, resulting in racial profiling. There have been incidents of police using excessive force, including torture, humiliation, and violence, even resulting in death. One notable incident occurred in 1996, where a Serbian Romani man, Nicola Jevremović, was beaten and arrested in front of his family for trying to pay a friend's parking fine. The police officers did not have a warrant, and Jevremović was initially fined for a misdemeanor and found guilty of "resisting arrest" in 1997. These incidents highlight ongoing issues with how authorities handle situations involving minorities and the use of excessive force in Turkmenistan and Austria.

The text discusses several incidents of authorities' mishandling of situations in Turkmenistan and Austria, with a focus on excessive force used against minorities. In Turkmenistan, there are allegations of excessive force and brutality in handling protests. In Austria, specifically Vienna, there have been instances of racial profiling, particularly towards African migrants, resulting in unjust treatment and violence. The text highlights the case of Nicola Jevremović, a Serbian Romani man, who was fined for a misdemeanor and found guilty of "resisting arrest" in 1997, and the case of Dr. C, an Austrian citizen of African descent, who was beaten unconscious by police in 1998 for driving the wrong way. Furthermore, the text mentions the death of Marcus Omofuma, a Nigerian asylum-seeker, who suffocated while being deported in 1999 due to excessive use of tape to restrain him. Lastly, the text includes the case of a 47-year-old woman who was beaten and arrested in 2015 for refusing a breathalyzer test, resulting in severe injuries and no response to her complaint. These incidents reflect ongoing issues with how authorities handle situations involving minorities and the use of excessive force in both countries.

In 2015, a 47-year-old woman sustained severe injuries, including a fractured coccyx and head/knee bruises, after being beaten by authorities and received no response when she filed a complaint. A year prior, a 27-year-old man, suspected of pickpocketing, was violently thrown to the ground while in police custody, with video evidence contradicting police claims of his resistance. From 2014-2015, 250 accusations of police misconduct were made in Vienna, but none resulted in charges, while 1,329 people were charged with "civil disorder". Amnesty International reported that from 1998-1999, few human rights violators were held accountable, and complainants often faced counter-charges. These incidents highlight Austria's ongoing issue of excessive force and mishandling situations involving minorities, with limited consequences for offending authorities.

The Council of Europe's 2014 report revealed that Austrian police have been accused of using excessive force against detainees and psychiatric patients, with insufficient investigations and accountability. Despite laws against hate speech and NGO-led initiatives, incidents of police brutality persist, often targeting minorities. The Austrian police have initiated measures such as body cameras and policy revisions to address police misconduct. However, Amnesty International calls for further government action to combat negative stereotypes and prejudice, which contribute to racially motivated police brutality.

Amnesty International recommends the Austrian government to take more action to combat negative stereotypes and prejudice that contribute to racially motivated police brutality, including considering disbanding the Bereitschaftspolizei due to their involvement in human rights violations. Additionally, they suggest adopting a National Action Plan against Racism, as required by the 2001 Durban Declaration and Programme of Action. In other news, following the 2001 national parliamentary report on police negligence in a series of pedophile murders, Belgium merged its three-tier police system into two forces operating on federal and local levels with integrated training programs and recruitment. Separately, Belarusian authorities faced criticism for stopping Ryanair Flight 4978 and detaining a Belarusian journalist and activist, Roman Protasevich, in May 2021.

After a national parliamentary report revealed police negligence in pedophile murder cases, Belgium combined its three-tier police system into two forces, one federal and one local, which, although independent, share training programs and recruitment. There are around 33,000 local police officers and 900 civilians serving in 196 regional forces. While Belgian law incorporates the UN's principles on the use of force and firearms by law enforcement officials, allegations of police mistreatment towards people and property increased from 2005 to 2011, with many cases involving assaults on individuals who no longer posed a threat. The Belgian judiciary has also been criticized for not informing the police watchdog, Committee P, of police criminal convictions, which is a violation of both Belgian law and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This issue gained attention after the death of Jonathan Jacob in Mortsel in 2010.

Following the unification of the Belgian police system and reports of police mistreatment, the European Court of Human Rights found Belgium guilty of human rights violations in a 2013 case involving police brutality. This decision came after an incident in Mortsel where a man, under the influence of amphetamines, was beaten by eight officers from the Special Intervention Unit despite being sedated, leading to his death. The court expressed concern about the use of physical violence by law enforcement officers, which violates individuals' dignity. In response, the Belgian League of Human Rights established the Observatory of Police Violence in 2013 to monitor police brutality and advocate for public policy changes to protect victims. Despite these efforts, other instances of police violence have been reported in Belgium.

After the 2013 ruling by the European Court of Human Rights that condemned Belgium for police brutality, leading to human rights violations, the Belgian League of Human Rights established the Observatory of Police Violence to monitor and address the issue. However, instances of police violence have continued to occur in Belgium. Notably, a four-year-old child named Mawda was killed in 2014 due to a police officer's actions, resulting in a suspended prison sentence and a small fine. In 2018, Lamine Bangoura died in his apartment due to excessive force used by eight policemen during an eviction. More recently, in 2019 and 2020, Mehdi and Adil, both Moroccan boys aged 17 and 19, were killed in separate incidents involving police cars. In 2021, Ibrahima was arrested for filming a police control. These cases highlight ongoing concerns about police violence in Belgium.

Following the establishment of the Observatory of Police Violence in Belgium after a 2013 human rights violation ruling, incidents of police brutality have persisted, involving a young child's death in 2014, a man's death during an eviction in 2018, and the fatalities of two minors in 2019-2020. In 2021, Ibrahima died in police custody after being arrested for filming a police control, with reports of his arrest being due to curfew violation despite it occurring before the curfew. His death sparked public outrage and protests. In contrast, Croatia's constitution prohibits torture, mistreatment, and cruel punishment, and its police force, previously militarized, has been known to use excessive force due to their training during the country's secession from Yugoslavia.

The militarized training of Croatia's police force in the 1990s has resulted in a persistent use of excessive force, as shown by the European Court of Human Rights' findings of inadequate investigations into violent attacks and the disregard of violence against minority groups, particularly the Romani. This is similar to the ongoing issue of police brutality in Belgium despite the establishment of the Observatory of Police Violence, with several incidents reported even after the 2013 human rights violation ruling. The Croatian police's treatment of the Romani minority is particularly concerning, as complaints of violent behavior towards them have been raised, but authorities have been reluctant to take action.

The European Commission against Racism and Intolerance has reported continuous abuse by Croatian police towards minority groups, especially the Romani, with authorities being reluctant to address it. Instances of violent and racist treatment towards Romani vendors have been noted, including a 2002 case where a pregnant woman was beaten. Additionally, Croatian police have been accused of using intimidation tactics, such as violence and deception, against refugees from certain nationalities, like Morocco, while favoring others, like Syrians, Iraqis, and Afghans. This behavior has been observed at the border between Serbia and Croatia.

The Danish police, consisting of around 11,000 officers, have seen a decrease in misconduct complaints from 2012 to 2015, with 0.05 complaints per officer in 2015. Most complaints are due to general misbehavior, but there have been instances of excessive force, such as an arrested individual in Christianshavn on March 15, 2016. The Danish Independent Police Complaints Authority is responsible for investigating these allegations. This summary stands in contrast to the continuous abuse and reluctance to address mistreatment of minority groups by Croatian police, as reported by the European Commission against Racism and Intolerance.

The Danish Independent Police Complaints Authority investigates allegations of police misconduct, such as instances of violence against arrested individuals, including a 2016 case in Christianshavn and a 2002 death in police custody. Another investigation in 2016 led to charges against two officers. There have been concerns about the thoroughness of investigations and accountability for officer misconduct. Amnesty International has called for new policies to investigate human rights violations. Criticism of the police also extends to their handling of situations like the 2009 removal of Iraqi refugees from a city church.

The text describes a 2009 incident where police were accused of using violence against Iraqi refugees and their supporters, leading to a large protest. The Danish Court of Appeal later found that the police had violated human rights conventions during a mass arrest at the 2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference. To prevent police misconduct, Danish police recruits receive extensive training at the National Police College, covering various subjects including human rights and management, lasting around three years. This is in contrast to US police academies, which provide an average of 19 weeks of classroom instruction. Previous investigations by the Danish Independent Police Complaints Authority have involved allegations of police violence and misconduct, including a 2016 case and a 2002 death in custody, with concerns about investigation thoroughness and accountability. Amnesty International has called for new policies to investigate human rights violations.

Following their extensive three-year training at the National Police College, Danish police recruits become police constables and are expected to handle conflicts effectively and carry out their duties professionally. The Independent Police Complaints Authority, an independent body that investigates criminal cases against police officers and determines misconduct complaints, holds them accountable to Danish, European, and international laws. This authority ensures that police use force only when necessary and justifiable, with consideration given to potential harm to third parties. To uphold these standards, victims of police misconduct are urged to report incidents to the Authority. In contrast, US police academies offer an average of just 19 weeks of classroom instruction. Despite previous allegations of police violence and concerns about investigation thoroughness in Denmark, Amnesty International recommends new policies to investigate human rights violations.

After losing independence to the Soviet Union and re-establishing its police force in 1990, Estonia merged its police and border guard agencies in 2010, creating the largest state agency with over 5000 employees. This organization, the Police and Border Guard Board, focuses on maintaining security, preventing and investigating crimes, managing EU borders, and administering citizenship and identity documents. From 2013 to 2015, crime rates in Estonia decreased by 10%. In contrast to the extensive three-year training of Danish police recruits, US police academies offer significantly less instruction time. Although Denmark has faced past allegations of police violence and calls for improved human rights violation investigations, the Independent Police Complaints Authority oversees police conduct, ensuring adherence to Danish, European, and international laws.

Following Estonia's regaining independence and merging its police and border guard agencies, the Police and Border Guard Board was formed to maintain security, manage EU borders, and oversee citizenship and identity documents. From 2013 to 2015, crime rates decreased by 10%. While police abuse is infrequent, it has occurred, such as during the 2007 Bronze Night riots. This event took place when the Bronze Soldier statue was moved, causing tension between Estonians and Russophones. One Russian protester died, and many were detained in overcrowded facilities, leading to some being held in cargo terminals. Those detained are advised to follow police instructions and request an interpreter if needed, ensuring document accuracy before signing.

During the Bronze Night riots in 2007, overcrowded detention centers led to detainees being held in cargo terminals. Allegations of police brutality emerged, with detainees, including women and teenagers, reportedly being subjected to harsh conditions and physical abuse. The police department denied these claims. The Office of the Prosecutor General received over 50 complaints and opened seven criminal cases, while the UN Committee against Torture expressed concerns about excessive force and lack of fundamental safeguards, such as access to legal assistance and contact with relatives.

The text discusses historical and contemporary issues of police brutality in France. During the Bronze Night riots in 2007, detainees faced harsh conditions and allegations of physical abuse, which the police denied. Similar concerns were raised by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International regarding excessive force and human rights violations towards Muslims during house raids. France's police ombudsman is handling numerous inquiries into police brutality, with hundreds arrested. A notable case is the death of Lamine Dieng in 2007 due to suffocation while restrained in a police van, with investigations still ongoing. This summary conveys the concept of longstanding and widespread police brutality allegations in France, with specific examples and ongoing investigations.

The investigation into Lamine Dieng's death due to police restraint in 2007 is ongoing, with concerns over the use of carotid restraint and unexplained bruises. France has faced criticism for police brutality, including from Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, and the Stolen Lives Collective, which advocates for families affected by police violence and racism within the French police force. Recent protests have highlighted the severe issue of police brutality, with authorities suppressing video evidence and Amnesty International reporting abuses during the yellow vests movement.

The text discusses the ongoing fight against police brutality in France, with concerns over racial bias and specific incidents such as the death of Lamine Dieng in 2007 and the killing of Nahel Merzouk in 2023. Protests have occurred, including the Yellow Vests movement in 2018, which faced police violence and led to Amnesty International reporting abuses. The text also references historical police brutality in Finland during the 1920s and 1930s and mentions occasional cases of police officers committing crimes while on duty in 2006. The overarching theme is the persistent issue of police brutality and the need for government action to address it.

The text reveals an increase in police misconduct cases in France, with around half being traffic-related offenses, often dismissed before reaching the prosecutor. Excessive force cases, making up around 20%, always proceed to the prosecutor except for minor assaults. Instances of severe abuse include a 2006 rape case involving a police officer and a 2007 beating at a Helsinki police station, resulting in an immigrant's severe injuries and a suspended sentence for the officer. This information reinforces the text's central theme of pervasive police brutality requiring government intervention.

The text describes several incidents of police misconduct in France, including severe abuse cases resulting in injuries and suspended sentences for the officers involved. This continues to highlight the issue of pervasive police brutality discussed in the previous text. In Germany, despite efforts to avoid historical mistakes, there is still a noted pattern of ill-treatment by police towards foreigners and ethnic minorities, as illustrated by the assault on a man in a wheelchair and a Romani man. These instances emphasize the need for government intervention to address police brutality.

Germany, despite being mindful of its past when implementing policing, faces ongoing issues of police brutality towards foreigners and ethnic minorities, as documented by approximately 2,000 annual complaints, with the actual number likely higher. Instances of police misconduct, such as the 1967 shooting of Benno Ohnesorg and the 1999 death of Aamir Ageeb during deportation, indicate a pattern of racism and xenophobia in these incidents. This information reinforces the urgency for government intervention to tackle police brutality, as previously mentioned in the context.

The text discusses several incidents of alleged police misconduct in Germany, which further highlight the problem of police brutality in the country. In 1999, Aamir Ageeb suffered fatal injuries during deportation, as police officers reportedly restrained him with tape and rope and forced his head down during take-off. In 2000, Josef Hoss was accused of possessing firearms and was beaten by a police officer, resulting in severe injuries and preventing him from working. No weapons were found during the investigation. In 2002, Stephan Neisius died after being kicked and hit by several police officers while handcuffed in a police station. Although the officers were convicted, none served prison time. In 2012, Teresa Z. was arrested and physically assaulted by a police officer, leaving her with a broken nose and eye socket. These instances underscore the need for government intervention to address police brutality, as previously mentioned.

The text discusses a specific incident of police brutality in Germany, where Teresa Z. was physically assaulted by officer Frank W. and sustained severe injuries. Frank W. served ten months in jail and paid a fine. The text also highlights the lack of a federal register for recording complaints about police misconduct, as each German state has its own police force and system of law. A study in 2019 found that police brutality in Germany rarely leads to complaints or trials, likely due to a low expectation of success. The text emphasizes Germany's obligation to uphold international human rights law and standards, which it has allegedly failed to do.

The 2019 study reveals that few complaints about police brutality in Germany are made due to a low expectation of success, and identifying individual officers is challenging since most states don't mandate IDs. Watchdog groups criticize the absence of independent bodies for probing police violence. Despite this, public trust in German police is high, leading to low public order and safety spending, and a relatively small police force. Despite instances of police brutality, the use of service weapons is infrequent. This approach to policing seems to create a perception of a more laid-back law enforcement style.

The German police seldom use their service weapons, with only 8 fatalities reported in the two years prior to August 2017, in contrast to the Greek Police, also known as the Hellenic Police, which has a history of police brutality dating back to 1976. The Greek Police, formed by merging the Gendarmerie and Urban Police Forces in 1984, have been involved in several brutal incidents, such as the killing of a 16-year-old activist in 1976 and the beating deaths of two protesters in 1980. Regrettably, police brutality continues to be a common occurrence during demonstrations that commemorate the 1973 uprising in Greece.

The 1973 uprising in Greece is still commemorated with protests that continue to experience police brutality. This issue has been particularly severe in recent years due to austerity measures causing financial hardship for many citizens, who have protested in response. The police have been reported to use excessive force, including tear gas, severe injuries, and unjustified detention of protesters. Instances of police misconduct have been severe, such as the alleged torture of four men in 2013, where they were beaten in custody, and the police provided manipulated photos to the media to downplay the abuse.

The 2013 alleged torture of four men and 2012 arrest of 15 anti-fascist protesters in Greece reveal ongoing police misconduct, involving excessive force, manipulated evidence, and retaliation against those who report it. Instances of brutality include beatings, burns from cigarettes, sleep deprivation, and false photographs. The Greek minister of citizen protection, Nikos Dendias, has been accused of supporting the police and dismissing allegations, even after forensic examinations confirm abuse. This has resulted in the firing of journalists who cover the incidents. Present-day police brutality in Greece primarily takes the form of unjustified physical violence against protesters and journalists, along with attempts to suppress evidence and discredit accusers.

The firing of two Greek journalists who discussed a Guardian report and the Amnesty International report's findings reveal the ongoing issue of police misconduct in Greece. This takes the form of unjustified physical violence towards protesters and journalists, as seen in numerous instances of excessive force, weapon misuse, and attacks on journalists. These actions, such as spraying chemical irritants at close range and striking students, particularly during the Athens Polytechnic uprising anniversary, infringe on freedom of expression and endanger vulnerable individuals, even those with medical conditions. Despite allegations and evidence, the Greek minister of citizen protection, Nikos Dendias, has been accused of supporting the police and disregarding abuse claims.

The text reveals that Greek police have been accused of using excessive force, leading to injuries requiring medical treatment for around 40 protesters. Amnesty International has criticized the Greek police for a culture of "abuse and impunity," as authorities have not adequately addressed the issue. A German exchange student was randomly beaten by riot police while eating with other students in the Exarheia district, despite posing no threat. The student's account highlights the brutal nature of the assault, as he was attacked by multiple officers and left without medical attention. These incidents suggest a pattern of unjustified violence and disregard for safety and well-being.

The text describes allegations of Greek police using excessive force, causing injuries to numerous protesters, including a German exchange student and journalists like Yannis Kafkas, Manolis Kipraios, Marios Lolos, and Rena Maniou. These incidents resulted in grave injuries, such as Kafkas' near-fatal head injury and Kipraios' permanent hearing loss. Amnesty International calls for investigations into these human rights violations and accountability for the officers involved. The pattern of unprovoked violence and disregard for safety is a concern.

The text discusses additional allegations of Greek police brutality, such as the severe beating of journalist Rena Maniou and the breaking of Dimitris Trimis' arm. It also mentions the use of protesters as human shields. No police officers have been prosecuted for these incidents, with the exception of the murder of Alexis Grigoropoulos in 2008 which led to nationwide riots. In contrast, the police force in Hungary, which consists of the National Bureau of Investigation and the Operational Police, has a history of holding officers accountable for misconduct, as seen when Hungary's Border Guards were merged with the police and held accountable for their actions. Amnesty International is calling for investigations and accountability for the officers involved in the Greek incidents, highlighting a pattern of unprovoked violence and disregard for safety.

The Hungarian police force, Rendőrség, is composed of the National Bureau of Investigation, Operational Police, and Terrorelhárítási Központ, which handle severe crimes, riot control, and counter-terrorism, respectively. With 44,923 employees, Rendőrség has struggled with brutality and corruption, particularly towards the Roma minority, as reported by Human Rights Watch in 1998. During the 2006 protests against Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsány, police used excessive force, including gas grenades and rubber bullets, against non-violent civilians, causing injuries and damage. This highlights a pattern of police brutality within Rendőrség.

The Hungarian police force, Rendőrség, has been accused of brutality and corruption, particularly towards minorities and during protests. This is attributed to inadequate police training, as the two-year police academy program focuses more on theoretical knowledge rather than practical skills. Compared to other countries, Hungary's program is longer than some but shorter than others. To improve, Hungary should enhance police training programs, providing ongoing assessments to ensure fair and ethical judgement in using force, in line with the severity of a crime or situation.

The Hungarian police force's brutality and corruption, particularly towards minorities and during protests, are said to result from insufficient practical training in their two-year academy program. Although Hungary's program is longer than some countries, it focuses more on theoretical knowledge. In contrast, Northern Ireland's Police Service (PSNI), which faced historical brutality issues due to controversial methods during the Troubles, could benefit from improved training too. To address this, Hungary and Northern Ireland should prioritize practical skills in their police education, ensuring fair and ethical use of force according to the gravity of a crime or situation.

The previous text discusses the historical brutality and corruption of the Northern Irish Police, specifically during the Troubles, where approximately 50,000 people were injured or maimed. The European Court of Human Rights confirmed instances of police brutality through five interrogation techniques, which were considered cruel and degrading treatment. Domestic courts only recognized these complaints in 2010, and currently, there are ongoing issues such as harassment towards children in low socio-economic areas and different treatment of Catholics due to the predominantly Protestant police force. To improve policing, practical skills and ethical conduct in various situations should be emphasized in police education, as mentioned in the context, in the case of Hungary and Northern Ireland.

The text discusses the ongoing issue of Catholics in Northern Ireland being subjected to harassment by the predominantly Protestant police force, despite the decrease in physical violence and brutality. Specific instances of harassment mentioned include spitting and discriminatory enforcement of laws. In contrast, the Republic of Ireland's police force, the Garda Síochána, is reported to have around 14,500 staff and allows the use of "reasonable force" as long as it is proportionate to the situation.

The criminal laws in Ireland permit the use of "reasonable force" by police, considering the situation's circumstances, and it can be deemed proportionate. Although excessive force is illegal, an officer acting instinctively for a valid reason might still use reasonable force, as per the Garda's acknowledgment. Instances of international concern have emerged due to the use of force by Irish police, with the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture investigating this issue in the Republic thrice over a decade. This summary discusses the police force's use of force in Ireland, both in the Republic and Northern Ireland, in the context of the preceding text about Catholic harassment by the Northern Irish police force.

The text discusses concerns over police use of force in both Ireland and Italy. In Ireland, instances of excessive force by the Garda have led to investigations by the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture and the engagement of independent Human Rights experts. This resulted in new procedures such as a complaints mechanism, disciplinary measures, and whistleblower protections. Similarly, in Italy, there have been issues with police violence since the 2000s, including beatings, murders, and the death of Carlo Giuliani during an anti-globalization protest in 2001.

In Italy, there have been cases of alleged police violence and killings, such as the death of Carlo Giuliani in 2001, where a police officer named Mario Placanica was held responsible but not charged. Placanica claimed that other officers were involved in Giuliani's death, but no one was arrested. In 2003, Marcello Lonzi died in his cell due to alleged torture, but no one was held accountable. Similarly, Federico Aldrovandi was killed in 2005 during an encounter with four policemen, which led to his torture and death. These instances highlight ongoing concerns over police use of force and accountability in Italy.

The text describes several incidents of alleged police violence and accountability issues in Italy. In one case, a man named Federico Aldrovandi was killed during an encounter with four policemen, who were later convicted and sentenced to three years and six months in prison for beating and torturing him. Another incident involved a schizophrenic man named Riccardo Rasman, who died from asphyxia after being beaten and gagged by four officers who were responding to a report of suspected gunshots, which were actually firecrackers. The officers were sentenced to six months in prison. The final incident concerns Aldo Bianzino, a carpenter who was arrested along with his wife for possessing a small amount of marijuana. He was separated from his wife at the police station and two days later, an officer asked his wife about Bianzino's heart condition. These cases highlight ongoing concerns about police use of force and accountability in Italy.

The text describes the experience of Aldo Bianzino's wife, Roberta Radici, after they were separated at a police station. Two days later, an officer asked Radici about her husband's heart condition, to which she replied that he was healthy. The officer informed her that Bianzino was in the hospital in critical condition. Three hours after being freed from her cell, Radici learned that her husband had died and an autopsy revealed signs of violence. A police officer was later sentenced for failing to provide assistance. The incident is another example of concerns about police use of force and accountability in Italy.

The group of friends, including Gabriele Sandri, were traveling to a football match when they were stopped by police. Sandri was shot and killed by a police officer, leading to protests and violence. The incident further highlights the issues of police use of force and accountability in Italy.

The text describes two incidents in Italy that highlight concerns about police use of force and accountability. In the first incident, a group of Lazio football supporters, including Gabriele Sandri, were involved in a fight with Juventus supporters. Police officer Luigi Spaccarotella intervened and fatally shot Sandri. Spaccarotella was sentenced to prison but was released with semi-liberty in 2017. In a separate incident, Giuseppe Uva was stopped by police and refused to show his documents, leading to his arrest. Uva died the next morning, and signs of violence were found on his body. Despite calls for charges against the eight officers involved, none were made. These incidents underscore the ongoing issues of police use of force and accountability in Italy.

The attorney general requested ten-year imprisonment for each of the eight officers involved in Giuseppe Uva's death, but no charges were brought. Uva's sister believes he was murdered, gaining support from Luigi Manconi. In a separate event, Stefano Cucchi, an Italian resident of Rome with epilepsy, was arrested for selling transparent packaging for money. Officers mistook him for a homeless foreigner, beat him, and continued to torture him in custody. Cucchi's worsening condition led to hospitalization, where he passed away a week later. These cases emphasize the persistent problems of police use of force and accountability in Italy.

After Stefano Cucchi's arrest, officers mistreated him, causing severe injuries and his eventual death in the hospital. His sister, Ilaria, became an activist for justice. In 2019, two officers were convicted for manslaughter, and in 2020, seven Carabinieri were arrested for various crimes, including torturing a Moroccan man and planting drugs on detainees. These incidents highlight the ongoing issues of police misconduct and accountability in Italy.

The text describes allegations of extensive police misconduct involving the same group of seven officers who were arrested in 2020. The officers are accused of torturing a Moroccan man, illegally arresting him and other individuals, and planting drugs on detainees. Specific incidents mentioned include an officer, Montella, punching the Moroccan man and later admitting to the torture, as well as a Nigerian man being beaten and arrested with photos showing him covered in blood. The officers are also accused of forcing a Brazilian woman to have sex with one of them through blackmail and threats, as well as consuming drugs and engaging in orgies with prostitutes inside the police station. The women were also beaten and threatened by the officers. These cases highlight the ongoing issue of police misconduct and accountability in Italy.

In 2019, Rio de Janeiro reported a record-breaking 1,814 police-involved killings, a number that rose to 1,423 for Black and Brown individuals. This trend continued in 2020, with the Brazilian Public Security Forum and São Paulo University estimating around 6,416 people killed by police, 78% of whom were Black or Brown. This violence disproportionately affects young, poor men, and the COVID-19 pandemic did not decrease these rates, which saw a 27.9% increase compared to 2019. This situation is often referred to as the "genocide of Black Brazilian youth." Rio de Janeiro remains the city with the highest rates of police-related killings.

The COVID-19 pandemic did not reduce police-related killings in Rio de Janeiro; instead, they increased by 27.9% compared to 2019. A report from the ISP indicates that Rio's police killed 741 people from January to May 2020, the highest rate in 22 years. This violence disproportionately affects Black and Brown individuals in favelas. Seventeen organizations from the Black movement, human rights, and favelas joined a political party to file a petition (ADPF 635) with Brazil's Supreme Court, requesting immediate suspension of police operations during the pandemic to protect life and dignity in these communities.

In May 2020, several organizations petitioned the Brazilian Supreme Court to immediately suspend police operations during the COVID-19 pandemic, arguing that continuing such operations would endanger lives and dignity in poor, predominantly Black and Brown communities in Rio de Janeiro. They highlighted the high mortality rates, police abuse cases, and property damage caused by police raids during the health crisis. The plea came after the police killed a 14-year-old boy, João Pedro Pinto, who was playing with cousins and friends in his family's backyard when a police raid occurred. Witnesses reported that the police shot at the group and threw grenades, causing the children to run into the house for protection. João Pedro was fatally shot in the abdomen, and his family was not able to see his body for 17 hours after the incident.

In May 2020, João Pedro Pinto, a 14-year-old boy, was fatally shot in the abdomen during a police raid in Rio de Janeiro, with witnesses reporting numerous bullets and grenades being fired. His family was unable to see his body for 17 hours and it was taken to a location 27 miles away. This incident sparked protests and became the central argument for the ADPF 635 petition, supported by Supreme Court Minister Edson Fachin, which aimed to suspend police operations during the COVID-19 pandemic in vulnerable communities. The Supreme Court unanimously voted to maintain the decision, imposing strict guidelines on authorized operations, such as avoiding body removal, preserving crime scenes, and not conducting operations near schools and hospitals. The Court also prohibited using helicopters for shooting and as operational bases, even after the pandemic.

The Supreme Court's decision mandates preserving crime scenes, avoiding body removal, and requiring thorough, unbiased investigations following the Minnesota Protocol. This ruling is seen as a significant step in advancing justice and improving the lives of those living in favelas, with support from various organizations like Rio de Janeiro Public Defense, Fala Akari, Papo Reto Collective, and others. The decision also prohibits using helicopters for shooting or as operational bases, even beyond the pandemic.

The text discusses additional organizations, such as Observatório de Favelas, Maré Vive, Instituto Marielle Franco, Cesec, and Fogo Cruzado, that supported a lawsuit advocating for improved policing practices in favelas. A research group from Federal Fluminense University in Rio de Janeiro, Grupo de Estudos dos Novos Ilegalismos (GENI), reported a decrease in mortality and criminality rates following the Supreme Court's decision to suspend certain police operations. However, Rio de Janeiro's police have expressed dissatisfaction with the ruling, claiming it hampers their work, and have not consistently adhered to the new requirements.

Following the Supreme Court's ruling to modify policing practices in favelas, some police operations still occurred without adhering to the new requirements. In the first two months of 2021, there was a 20% increase in police-related killings compared to the same period in 2020. A notable example is the Jacarezinho Favela raid on May 6, where 28 people were killed, which was deemed successful by police forces and the government. However, human rights activists criticized illegal actions, such as altering the crime scene and invading homes. This incident is known as the city's biggest slaughter and is under investigation. A month later, Kathlen Romeu, a 24-year-old pregnant Black woman, was fatally shot by a police officer during an allegedly illegal operation. The police officer reportedly hid in a neighbor's house to ambush criminals, according to the Brazilian Bar Association's Human Rights Commission.

Post-Supreme Court ruling, police operations in Rio de Janeiro's favelas continue with disregard for new guidelines, leading to a 20% rise in police-related killings in early 2021. The Jacarezinho Favela raid and Kathlen Romeu's death spark controversy. The Brazilian Bar Association's Human Rights Commission deems Kathlen's killing's operation illegal, with the officer hiding in a neighbor's house. In Colombia, protests against police brutality started in Bogotá in September 2020, following Javier Ordóñez's death in police custody, resulting in multiple fatalities and injuries. Chile's Carabineros face investigations for power abuse and police brutality, particularly towards students and the Mapuche people, as seen in Camilo Catrillanca's case.

Following the death of Camilo Catrillanca in Chile, it was discovered that the Carabineros' account of him attacking police officers was false. A video showed a police officer shooting Camilo while he was driving a tractor. The officer later admitted to destroying the SD card that contained the footage, claiming it had personal content. This incident is part of a larger pattern of police brutality and abuse of power by the Carabineros, including the use of hardened rubber bullets and tear gas causing hundreds of eye injuries during the 2019-2020 Chilean protests. Notable cases include Gustavo Gatica and Fabiola Campillai losing their vision completely.

The 2014 and 2017 Venezuelan protests were marked by significant human rights violations, as reported by Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, and the UN Human Rights Office. In these instances, security forces exceeded standard protest handling practices, employing methods such as rubber pellets, tear gas, live ammunition, and torture against detained protestors. This led to hundreds of individuals being tortured and at least 73 protesters' deaths in 2017. Notably, Gustavo Gatica and Fabiola Campillai are two Chilean victims who suffered complete vision loss due to police brutality, drawing parallels with the Venezuelan cases.

The 2014 and 2017 Venezuelan protests were marred by extensive human rights abuses, as reported by various organizations. Security forces, including the national guard, national police, and local police, were accused of using excessive force, such as rubber pellets, tear gas, live ammunition, and torture, leading to hundreds of torture cases and over 73 protester deaths in 2017. Many victims suffered gunshot wounds, with numerous fatalities caused by authorities and pro-government groups. Unlawful home invasions and theft occurred in Caracas and four states, and security forces were reported to have fired tear gas canisters at close range to inflict harm. These actions aimed to suppress dissent and prevent protesters from gathering and petitioning public institutions.

The 2014 and 2017 Venezuelan protests were marked by severe human rights violations, including the use of excessive force by security forces. Monica Kräuter, a chemist and teacher, reported that expired tear gas, which can break down into harmful substances, was used during the protests. Additionally, tear gas was fired near hospitals, residences, and health centers, as denounced by the Venezuelan Observatory of Health. High-level government officials, such as José Antonio Benavides Torres, Vladimir Padrino López, Néstor Reverol, Carlos Alfredo Pérez Ampueda, Gustavo González López, and Siria Venero de Guerrero, were accused by Human Rights Watch of being responsible for these abuses committed by Venezuelan security forces.

Venezuelan officials, including high-level ones, have been accused of human rights abuses during the 2014 and 2017 protests, such as using excessive force and causing harm to protesters. Human rights organizations, including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, have denounced these actions and alleged that they are part of a premeditated policy to suppress criticism. Reports of torture, beatings, and other mistreatment of detainees have been made by organizations like Foro Penal. Instances of forced consumption of offensive substances and physical abuse have been documented, with officials using tear gas and other methods to intimidate and harm protesters. Despite these allegations, Venezuelan authorities have denied any wrongdoing and praised the actions of security forces.

The text describes additional examples of alleged abuse by Venezuelan officials during protests, specifically forced consumption of pasta mixed with grass and excrement. This mistreatment was reportedly carried out by forcing open detainees' mouths with tear gas dust and pushing the repugnant mixture in, compelling them to swallow it. These actions are part of the broader pattern of human rights violations denounced by organizations such as Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International.
